defs.docs:
The ignore crate provides a fast recursive directory iterator that respects
various filters such as globs, file types and `.gitignore` files. The precise
matching rules and precedence is explained in the documentation for
`WalkBuilder`.

attributes.value: deny(missing_docs)

defs.name: gitignore
defs.docs:
The gitignore module provides a way to match globs from a gitignore file
against file paths.

attributes.value:
*
The gitignore module provides a way to match globs from a gitignore file
against file paths.

Note that this module implements the specification as described in the
`gitignore` man page from scratch. That is, this module does *not* shell out to
the `git` command line tool.
*/

defs.name: Glob
defs.docs: Glob represents a single glob in a gitignore file.

attributes.value: / Glob represents a single glob in a gitignore file.
/ This is used to report information about the highest precedent glob that
/ matched in one or more gitignore files.

defs.name: from
defs.docs: Returns the file path that defined this glob.

attributes.value: / Returns the file path that defined this glob.

defs.name: original
defs.docs: The original glob as it was defined in a gitignore file.

attributes.value: / The original glob as it was defined in a gitignore file.

defs.name: actual
defs.docs:
The actual glob that was compiled to respect gitignore
 semantics.

attributes.value: / The actual glob that was compiled to respect gitignore
/ semantics.

defs.name: is_whitelist
defs.docs: Whether this was a whitelisted glob or not.

attributes.value: / Whether this was a whitelisted glob or not.

defs.name: is_only_dir
defs.docs: Whether this glob must match a directory or not.

attributes.value: / Whether this glob must match a directory or not.

defs.name: Gitignore
defs.docs:
Gitignore is a matcher for the globs in one or more gitignore files
 in the same directory.

attributes.value: / Gitignore is a matcher for the globs in one or more gitignore files
/ in the same directory.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Creates a new gitignore matcher from the gitignore file path given.

attributes.value: / Creates a new gitignore matcher from the gitignore file path given.
/ If it's desirable to include multiple gitignore files in a single
/ matcher, or read gitignore globs from a different source, then
/ use `GitignoreBuilder`.
/ This always returns a valid matcher, even if it's empty. In particular,
/ a Gitignore file can be partially valid, e.g., when one glob is invalid
/ but the rest aren't.
/ Note that I/O errors are ignored. For more granular control over
/ errors, use `GitignoreBuilder`.

defs.name: global
defs.docs:
Creates a new gitignore matcher from the global ignore file, if one
 exists.

attributes.value: / Creates a new gitignore matcher from the global ignore file, if one
/ exists.
/ The global config file path is specified by git's `core.excludesFile`
/ config option.
/ Git's config file location is `$HOME/.gitconfig`. If `$HOME/.gitconfig`
/ does not exist or does not specify `core.excludesFile`, then
/ `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/ignore` is read. If `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME` is not
/ set or is empty, then `$HOME/.config/git/ignore` is used instead.

defs.name: empty
defs.docs: Creates a new empty gitignore matcher that never matches anything.

attributes.value: / Creates a new empty gitignore matcher that never matches anything.
/ Its path is empty.

defs.name: path
defs.docs: Returns the directory containing this gitignore matcher.

attributes.value: / Returns the directory containing this gitignore matcher.
/ All matches are done relative to this path.

defs.name: is_empty
defs.docs:
Returns true if and only if this gitignore has zero globs, and
 therefore never matches any file path.

attributes.value: / Returns true if and only if this gitignore has zero globs, and
/ therefore never matches any file path.

defs.name: len
defs.docs:
Returns the total number of globs, which should be equivalent to
 `num_ignores + num_whitelists`.

attributes.value: / Returns the total number of globs, which should be equivalent to
/ `num_ignores + num_whitelists`.

defs.name: num_ignores
defs.docs: Returns the total number of ignore globs.

attributes.value: / Returns the total number of ignore globs.

defs.name: num_whitelists
defs.docs: Returns the total number of whitelisted globs.

attributes.value: / Returns the total number of whitelisted globs.

defs.name: matched
defs.value: pub fn matched<P: AsRef<Path>>(&Self, P, bool) -> Match<&Glob>
defs.docs:
Returns whether the given path (file or directory) matched a pattern in
 this gitignore matcher.

attributes.value: / Returns whether the given path (file or directory) matched a pattern in
/ this gitignore matcher.
/ `is_dir` should be true if the path refers to a directory and false
/ otherwise.
/ The given path is matched relative to the path given when building
/ the matcher. Specifically, before matching `path`, its prefix (as
/ determined by a common suffix of the directory containing this
/ gitignore) is stripped. If there is no common suffix/prefix overlap,
/ then `path` is assumed to be relative to this matcher.

defs.name: matched_path_or_any_parents
defs.value:
pub fn matched_path_or_any_parents<P: AsRef<Path>>(&Self, P, bool)
-> Match<&Glob>
defs.docs:
Returns whether the given path (file or directory, and expected to be
 under the root) or any of its parent directories (up to the root)
 matched a pattern in this gitignore matcher.

attributes.value: / Returns whether the given path (file or directory, and expected to be
/ under the root) or any of its parent directories (up to the root)
/ matched a pattern in this gitignore matcher.
/ NOTE: This method is more expensive than walking the directory hierarchy
/ top-to-bottom and matching the entries. But, is easier to use in cases
/ when a list of paths are available without a hierarchy.
/ `is_dir` should be true if the path refers to a directory and false
/ otherwise.
/ The given path is matched relative to the path given when building
/ the matcher. Specifically, before matching `path`, its prefix (as
/ determined by a common suffix of the directory containing this
/ gitignore) is stripped. If there is no common suffix/prefix overlap,
/ then `path` is assumed to be relative to this matcher.
/ # Panics
/ This method panics if the given file path is not under the root path
/ of this matcher.

defs.name: GitignoreBuilder
defs.docs: Builds a matcher for a single set of globs from a .gitignore file.

attributes.value: / Builds a matcher for a single set of globs from a .gitignore file.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create a new builder for a gitignore file.

attributes.value: / Create a new builder for a gitignore file.
/ The path given should be the path at which the globs for this gitignore
/ file should be matched. Note that paths are always matched relative
/ to the root path given here. Generally, the root path should correspond
/ to the *directory* containing a `.gitignore` file.

defs.name: build
defs.docs: Builds a new matcher from the globs added so far.

attributes.value: / Builds a new matcher from the globs added so far.
/ Once a matcher is built, no new globs can be added to it.

defs.name: build_global
defs.docs:
Build a global gitignore matcher using the configuration in this
 builder.

attributes.value: / Build a global gitignore matcher using the configuration in this
/ builder.
/ This consumes ownership of the builder unlike `build` because it
/ must mutate the builder to add the global gitignore globs.
/ Note that this ignores the path given to this builder's constructor
/ and instead derives the path automatically from git's global
/ configuration.

defs.name: add
defs.value: pub fn add<P: AsRef<Path>>(&mut Self, P) -> Option<Error>
defs.docs: Add each glob from the file path given.

attributes.value: / Add each glob from the file path given.
/ The file given should be formatted as a `gitignore` file.
/ Note that partial errors can be returned. For example, if there was
/ a problem adding one glob, an error for that will be returned, but
/ all other valid globs will still be added.

defs.name: add_line
defs.value:
pub fn add_line(&mut Self, Option<PathBuf>, &str)
-> Result<&mut GitignoreBuilder, Error>
defs.docs: Add a line from a gitignore file to this builder.

attributes.value: / Add a line from a gitignore file to this builder.
/ If this line came from a particular `gitignore` file, then its path
/ should be provided here.
/ If the line could not be parsed as a glob, then an error is returned.
allow(deprecated)

defs.name: case_insensitive
defs.value:
pub fn case_insensitive(&mut Self, bool)
-> Result<&mut GitignoreBuilder, Error>
defs.docs: Toggle whether the globs should be matched case insensitively or not.

attributes.value: / Toggle whether the globs should be matched case insensitively or not.
/ When this option is changed, only globs added after the change will be
/ affected.
/ This is disabled by default.

defs.name: overrides
defs.docs:
The overrides module provides a way to specify a set of override globs.
This provides functionality similar to `--include` or `--exclude` in command
line tools.

attributes.value:
*
The overrides module provides a way to specify a set of override globs.
This provides functionality similar to `--include` or `--exclude` in command
line tools.
*/

defs.name: Glob
defs.docs: Glob represents a single glob in an override matcher.

attributes.value: / Glob represents a single glob in an override matcher.
/ This is used to report information about the highest precedent glob
/ that matched.
/ Note that not all matches necessarily correspond to a specific glob. For
/ example, if there are one or more whitelist globs and a file path doesn't
/ match any glob in the set, then the file path is considered to be ignored.
/ The lifetime `'a` refers to the lifetime of the matcher that produced
/ this glob.

defs.name: Override
defs.docs: Manages a set of overrides provided explicitly by the end user.

attributes.value: / Manages a set of overrides provided explicitly by the end user.

defs.name: empty
defs.docs: Returns an empty matcher that never matches any file path.

attributes.value: / Returns an empty matcher that never matches any file path.

defs.name: path
defs.docs: Returns the directory of this override set.

attributes.value: / Returns the directory of this override set.
/ All matches are done relative to this path.

defs.name: is_empty
defs.docs: Returns true if and only if this matcher is empty.

attributes.value: / Returns true if and only if this matcher is empty.
/ When a matcher is empty, it will never match any file path.

defs.name: num_ignores
defs.docs: Returns the total number of ignore globs.

attributes.value: / Returns the total number of ignore globs.

defs.name: num_whitelists
defs.docs: Returns the total number of whitelisted globs.

attributes.value: / Returns the total number of whitelisted globs.

defs.name: matched
defs.value: pub fn matched<'a, P: AsRef<Path>>(&'a Self, P, bool) -> Match<Glob>
defs.docs:
Returns whether the given file path matched a pattern in this override
 matcher.

attributes.value: / Returns whether the given file path matched a pattern in this override
/ matcher.
/ `is_dir` should be true if the path refers to a directory and false
/ otherwise.
/ If there are no overrides, then this always returns `Match::None`.
/ If there is at least one whitelist override and `is_dir` is false, then
/ this never returns `Match::None`, since non-matches are interpreted as
/ ignored.
/ The given path is matched to the globs relative to the path given
/ when building the override matcher. Specifically, before matching
/ `path`, its prefix (as determined by a common suffix of the directory
/ given) is stripped. If there is no common suffix/prefix overlap, then
/ `path` is assumed to reside in the same directory as the root path for
/ this set of overrides.

defs.name: OverrideBuilder
defs.docs: Builds a matcher for a set of glob overrides.

attributes.value: / Builds a matcher for a set of glob overrides.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create a new override builder.

attributes.value: / Create a new override builder.
/ Matching is done relative to the directory path provided.

defs.name: build
defs.docs: Builds a new override matcher from the globs added so far.

attributes.value: / Builds a new override matcher from the globs added so far.
/ Once a matcher is built, no new globs can be added to it.

defs.name: add
defs.value: pub fn add(&mut Self, &str) -> Result<&mut OverrideBuilder, Error>
defs.docs: Add a glob to the set of overrides.

attributes.value: / Add a glob to the set of overrides.
/ Globs provided here have precisely the same semantics as a single
/ line in a `gitignore` file, where the meaning of `!` is inverted:
/ namely, `!` at the beginning of a glob will ignore a file. Without `!`,
/ all matches of the glob provided are treated as whitelist matches.

defs.name: case_insensitive
defs.value:
pub fn case_insensitive(&mut Self, bool)
-> Result<&mut OverrideBuilder, Error>
defs.docs: Toggle whether the globs should be matched case insensitively or not.

attributes.value: / Toggle whether the globs should be matched case insensitively or not.
/ When this option is changed, only globs added after the change will be affected.
/ This is disabled by default.

defs.name: types
defs.docs:
The types module provides a way of associating globs on file names to file
types.

defs.name: Glob
defs.docs: Glob represents a single glob in a set of file type definitions.

attributes.value: / Glob represents a single glob in a set of file type definitions.
/ There may be more than one glob for a particular file type.
/ This is used to report information about the highest precedent glob
/ that matched.
/ Note that not all matches necessarily correspond to a specific glob.
/ For example, if there are one or more selections and a file path doesn't
/ match any of those selections, then the file path is considered to be
/ ignored.
/ The lifetime `'a` refers to the lifetime of the underlying file type
/ definition, which corresponds to the lifetime of the file type matcher.

defs.name: file_type_def
defs.docs:
Return the file type definition that matched, if one exists. A file type
 definition always exists when a specific definition matches a file
 path.

attributes.value: / Return the file type definition that matched, if one exists. A file type
/ definition always exists when a specific definition matches a file
/ path.

defs.name: FileTypeDef
defs.docs: A single file type definition.

attributes.value: / A single file type definition.
/ File type definitions can be retrieved in aggregate from a file type
/ matcher. File type definitions are also reported when its responsible
/ for a match.

defs.docs: Return the name of this file type.

attributes.value: / Return the name of this file type.

defs.name: globs
defs.docs: Return the globs used to recognize this file type.

defs.docs: Returns true if and only if this matcher has zero selections.

defs.name: definitions
defs.docs: Return the set of current file type definitions.

defs.name: matched
defs.value: pub fn matched<'a, P: AsRef<Path>>(&'a Self, P, bool) -> Match<Glob>
defs.docs: Returns a match for the given path against this file type matcher.

attributes.value: / Returns a match for the given path against this file type matcher.
/ The path is considered whitelisted if it matches a selected file type.
/ The path is considered ignored if it matches a negated file type.
/ If at least one file type is selected and `path` doesn't match, then
/ the path is also considered ignored.

defs.name: TypesBuilder
defs.docs:
TypesBuilder builds a type matcher from a set of file type definitions and
 a set of file type selections.

attributes.value: / TypesBuilder builds a type matcher from a set of file type definitions and
/ a set of file type selections.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create a new builder for a file type matcher.

attributes.value: / Create a new builder for a file type matcher.
/ The builder contains *no* type definitions to start with. A set
/ of default type definitions can be added with `add_defaults`, and
/ additional type definitions can be added with `select` and `negate`.

defs.name: build
defs.docs:
Build the current set of file type definitions *and* selections into
 a file type matcher.

attributes.value: / Build the current set of file type definitions *and* selections into
/ a file type matcher.

defs.name: definitions
defs.docs: Return the set of current file type definitions.

attributes.value: / Return the set of current file type definitions.
/ Definitions and globs are sorted.

defs.name: select
defs.docs: Select the file type given by `name`.

attributes.value: / Select the file type given by `name`.
/ If `name` is `all`, then all file types currently defined are selected.

defs.name: negate
defs.docs: Ignore the file type given by `name`.

attributes.value: / Ignore the file type given by `name`.
/ If `name` is `all`, then all file types currently defined are negated.

defs.docs: Clear any file type definitions for the type name given.

attributes.value: / Clear any file type definitions for the type name given.

defs.name: add
defs.value: pub fn add(&mut Self, &str, &str) -> Result<(), Error>
defs.docs:
Add a new file type definition. `name` can be arbitrary and `pat`
 should be a glob recognizing file paths belonging to the `name` type.

attributes.value: / Add a new file type definition. `name` can be arbitrary and `pat`
/ should be a glob recognizing file paths belonging to the `name` type.
/ If `name` is `all` or otherwise contains any character that is not a
/ Unicode letter or number, then an error is returned.

defs.name: add_def
defs.value: pub fn add_def(&mut Self, &str) -> Result<(), Error>
defs.docs:
Add a new file type definition specified in string form. There are two
 valid formats:
 1. `{name}:{glob}`.  This defines a 'root' definition that associates the
     given name with the given glob.
 2. `{name}:include:{comma-separated list of already defined names}.
     This defines an 'include' definition that associates the given name
     with the definitions of the given existing types.
 Names may not include any characters that are not
 Unicode letters or numbers.

attributes.value: / Add a new file type definition specified in string form. There are two
/ valid formats:
/ 1. `{name}:{glob}`.  This defines a 'root' definition that associates the
/     given name with the given glob.
/ 2. `{name}:include:{comma-separated list of already defined names}.
/     This defines an 'include' definition that associates the given name
/     with the definitions of the given existing types.
/ Names may not include any characters that are not
/ Unicode letters or numbers.

defs.docs: Add a set of default file type definitions.

attributes.value: / Returns the depth at which this entry was created relative to the root.

defs.name: error
defs.docs: Returns an error, if one exists, associated with processing this entry.

attributes.value: / Returns an error, if one exists, associated with processing this entry.
/ An example of an error is one that occurred while parsing an ignore
/ file. Errors related to traversing a directory tree itself are reported
/ as part of yielding the directory entry, and not with this method.

defs.name: WalkBuilder
defs.docs: WalkBuilder builds a recursive directory iterator.

attributes.value: / WalkBuilder builds a recursive directory iterator.
/ The builder supports a large number of configurable options. This includes
/ specific glob overrides, file type matching, toggling whether hidden
/ files are ignored or not, and of course, support for respecting gitignore
/ files.
/ By default, all ignore files found are respected. This includes `.ignore`,
/ `.gitignore`, `.git/info/exclude` and even your global gitignore
/ globs, usually found in `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/ignore`.
/ Some standard recursive directory options are also supported, such as
/ limiting the recursive depth or whether to follow symbolic links (disabled
/ by default).
/ # Ignore rules
/ There are many rules that influence whether a particular file or directory
/ is skipped by this iterator. Those rules are documented here. Note that
/ the rules assume a default configuration.
/ * First, glob overrides are checked. If a path matches a glob override,
/ then matching stops. The path is then only skipped if the glob that matched
/ the path is an ignore glob. (An override glob is a whitelist glob unless it
/ starts with a `!`, in which case it is an ignore glob.)
/ * Second, ignore files are checked. Ignore files currently only come from
/ git ignore files (`.gitignore`, `.git/info/exclude` and the configured
/ global gitignore file), plain `.ignore` files, which have the same format
/ as gitignore files, or explicitly added ignore files. The precedence order
/ is: `.ignore`, `.gitignore`, `.git/info/exclude`, global gitignore and
/ finally explicitly added ignore files. Note that precedence between
/ different types of ignore files is not impacted by the directory hierarchy;
/ any `.ignore` file overrides all `.gitignore` files. Within each precedence
/ level, more nested ignore files have a higher precedence than less nested
/ ignore files.
/ * Third, if the previous step yields an ignore match, then all matching
/ is stopped and the path is skipped. If it yields a whitelist match, then
/ matching continues. A whitelist match can be overridden by a later matcher.
/ * Fourth, unless the path is a directory, the file type matcher is run on
/ the path. As above, if it yields an ignore match, then all matching is
/ stopped and the path is skipped. If it yields a whitelist match, then
/ matching continues.
/ * Fifth, if the path hasn't been whitelisted and it is hidden, then the
/ path is skipped.
/ * Sixth, unless the path is a directory, the size of the file is compared
/ against the max filesize limit. If it exceeds the limit, it is skipped.
/ * Seventh, if the path has made it this far then it is yielded in the
/ iterator.

defs.name: new
defs.docs:
Create a new builder for a recursive directory iterator for the
 directory given.

attributes.value: / Create a new builder for a recursive directory iterator for the
/ directory given.
/ Note that if you want to traverse multiple different directories, it
/ is better to call `add` on this builder than to create multiple
/ `Walk` values.

defs.name: build
defs.docs: Build a new `Walk` iterator.

attributes.value: / Build a new `Walk` iterator.

defs.name: build_parallel
defs.docs: Build a new `WalkParallel` iterator.

attributes.value: / Build a new `WalkParallel` iterator.
/ Note that this *doesn't* return something that implements `Iterator`.
/ Instead, the returned value must be run with a closure. e.g.,
/ `builder.build_parallel().run(|| |path| println!("{:?}", path))`.

defs.name: add
defs.value: pub fn add<P: AsRef<Path>>(&mut Self, P) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Add a file path to the iterator.

attributes.value: / Add a file path to the iterator.
/ Each additional file path added is traversed recursively. This should
/ be preferred over building multiple `Walk` iterators since this
/ enables reusing resources across iteration.

defs.name: max_depth
defs.value: pub fn max_depth(&mut Self, Option<usize>) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: The maximum depth to recurse.

attributes.value: / The maximum depth to recurse.
/ The default, `None`, imposes no depth restriction.

defs.name: follow_links
defs.value: pub fn follow_links(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Whether to follow symbolic links or not.

attributes.value: / Whether to follow symbolic links or not.

defs.name: max_filesize
defs.value: pub fn max_filesize(&mut Self, Option<u64>) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Whether to ignore files above the specified limit.

attributes.value: / Whether to ignore files above the specified limit.

defs.name: threads
defs.value: pub fn threads(&mut Self, usize) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: The number of threads to use for traversal.

attributes.value: / The number of threads to use for traversal.
/ Note that this only has an effect when using `build_parallel`.
/ The default setting is `0`, which chooses the number of threads
/ automatically using heuristics.

defs.name: add_ignore
defs.value: pub fn add_ignore<P: AsRef<Path>>(&mut Self, P) -> Option<Error>
defs.docs: Add a global ignore file to the matcher.

attributes.value: / Add a global ignore file to the matcher.
/ This has lower precedence than all other sources of ignore rules.
/ If there was a problem adding the ignore file, then an error is
/ returned. Note that the error may indicate *partial* failure. For
/ example, if an ignore file contains an invalid glob, all other globs
/ are still applied.

defs.name: add_custom_ignore_filename
defs.value:
pub fn add_custom_ignore_filename<S: AsRef<OsStr>>(&mut Self, S)
-> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Add a custom ignore file name

attributes.value: / Add a custom ignore file name
/ These ignore files have higher precedence than all other ignore files.
/ When specifying multiple names, earlier names have lower precedence than
/ later names.

defs.name: overrides
defs.value: pub fn overrides(&mut Self, Override) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Add an override matcher.

attributes.value: / Add an override matcher.
/ By default, no override matcher is used.
/ This overrides any previous setting.

defs.name: types
defs.value: pub fn types(&mut Self, Types) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Add a file type matcher.

attributes.value: / Add a file type matcher.
/ By default, no file type matcher is used.
/ This overrides any previous setting.

defs.name: standard_filters
defs.value: pub fn standard_filters(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Enables all the standard ignore filters.

attributes.value: / Enables all the standard ignore filters.
/ This toggles, as a group, all the filters that are enabled by default:
/ - [hidden()](#method.hidden)
/ - [parents()](#method.parents)
/ - [ignore()](#method.ignore)
/ - [git_ignore()](#method.git_ignore)
/ - [git_global()](#method.git_global)
/ - [git_exclude()](#method.git_exclude)
/ They may still be toggled individually after calling this function.
/ This is (by definition) enabled by default.

defs.name: hidden
defs.value: pub fn hidden(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Enables ignoring hidden files.

attributes.value: / Enables ignoring hidden files.
/ This is enabled by default.

defs.name: parents
defs.value: pub fn parents(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Enables reading ignore files from parent directories.

attributes.value: / Enables reading ignore files from parent directories.
/ If this is enabled, then .gitignore files in parent directories of each
/ file path given are respected. Otherwise, they are ignored.
/ This is enabled by default.

defs.name: ignore
defs.value: pub fn ignore(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Enables reading `.ignore` files.

attributes.value: / Enables reading `.ignore` files.
/ `.ignore` files have the same semantics as `gitignore` files and are
/ supported by search tools such as ripgrep and The Silver Searcher.
/ This is enabled by default.

defs.name: git_global
defs.value: pub fn git_global(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs:
Enables reading a global gitignore file, whose path is specified in
 git's `core.excludesFile` config option.

attributes.value: / Enables reading a global gitignore file, whose path is specified in
/ git's `core.excludesFile` config option.
/ Git's config file location is `$HOME/.gitconfig`. If `$HOME/.gitconfig`
/ does not exist or does not specify `core.excludesFile`, then
/ `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/ignore` is read. If `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME` is not
/ set or is empty, then `$HOME/.config/git/ignore` is used instead.
/ This is enabled by default.

defs.name: git_ignore
defs.value: pub fn git_ignore(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Enables reading `.gitignore` files.

attributes.value: / Enables reading `.gitignore` files.
/ `.gitignore` files have match semantics as described in the `gitignore`
/ man page.
/ This is enabled by default.

defs.name: git_exclude
defs.value: pub fn git_exclude(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Enables reading `.git/info/exclude` files.

attributes.value: / Enables reading `.git/info/exclude` files.
/ `.git/info/exclude` files have match semantics as described in the
/ `gitignore` man page.
/ This is enabled by default.

defs.name: require_git
defs.value: pub fn require_git(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs:
Whether a git repository is required to apply git-related ignore
 rules (global rules, .gitignore and local exclude rules).

attributes.value: / Whether a git repository is required to apply git-related ignore
/ rules (global rules, .gitignore and local exclude rules).
/ When disabled, git-related ignore rules are applied even when searching
/ outside a git repository.

defs.name: ignore_case_insensitive
defs.value: pub fn ignore_case_insensitive(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Process ignore files case insensitively

attributes.value: / Process ignore files case insensitively
/ This is disabled by default.

defs.name: sort_by_file_path
defs.value:
pub fn sort_by_file_path<F>(&mut Self, F) -> &mut WalkBuilder where
F: Fn(&Path, &Path) -> cmp::Ordering + Send + Sync + 'static
defs.docs: Set a function for sorting directory entries by their path.

attributes.value: / Set a function for sorting directory entries by their path.
/ If a compare function is set, the resulting iterator will return all
/ paths in sorted order. The compare function will be called to compare
/ entries from the same directory.
/ This is like `sort_by_file_name`, except the comparator accepts
/ a `&Path` instead of the base file name, which permits it to sort by
/ more criteria.
/ This method will override any previous sorter set by this method or
/ by `sort_by_file_name`.
/ Note that this is not used in the parallel iterator.

defs.name: sort_by_file_name
defs.value:
pub fn sort_by_file_name<F>(&mut Self, F) -> &mut WalkBuilder where
F: Fn(&OsStr, &OsStr) -> cmp::Ordering + Send + Sync + 'static
defs.docs: Set a function for sorting directory entries by file name.

attributes.value: / Set a function for sorting directory entries by file name.
/ If a compare function is set, the resulting iterator will return all
/ paths in sorted order. The compare function will be called to compare
/ names from entries from the same directory using only the name of the
/ entry.
/ This method will override any previous sorter set by this method or
/ by `sort_by_file_path`.
/ Note that this is not used in the parallel iterator.

defs.name: same_file_system
defs.value: pub fn same_file_system(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs: Do not cross file system boundaries.

attributes.value: / Do not cross file system boundaries.
/ When this option is enabled, directory traversal will not descend into
/ directories that are on a different file system from the root path.
/ Currently, this option is only supported on Unix and Windows. If this
/ option is used on an unsupported platform, then directory traversal
/ will immediately return an error and will not yield any entries.

defs.name: skip_stdout
defs.value: pub fn skip_stdout(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut WalkBuilder
defs.docs:
Do not yield directory entries that are believed to correspond to
 stdout.

attributes.value: / Do not yield directory entries that are believed to correspond to
/ stdout.
/ This is useful when a command is invoked via shell redirection to a
/ file that is also being read. For example, `grep -r foo ./ > results`
/ might end up trying to search `results` even though it is also writing
/ to it, which could cause an unbounded feedback loop. Setting this
/ option prevents this from happening by skipping over the `results`
/ file.
/ This is disabled by default.

defs.name: filter_entry
defs.value:
pub fn filter_entry

(&mut Self, P) -> &mut WalkBuilder where P: Fn(&DirEntry) -> bool + Send + Sync + 'static
defs.docs:
Yields only entries which satisfy the given predicate and skips
 descending into directories that do not satisfy the given predicate.

attributes.value: / Yields only entries which satisfy the given predicate and skips
/ descending into directories that do not satisfy the given predicate.
/ The predicate is applied to all entries. If the predicate is
/ true, iteration carries on as normal. If the predicate is false, the
/ entry is ignored and if it is a directory, it is not descended into.
/ Note that the errors for reading entries that may not satisfy the
/ predicate will still be yielded.

defs.name: Walk
defs.docs:
Walk is a recursive directory iterator over file paths in one or more
 directories.

attributes.value: / Walk is a recursive directory iterator over file paths in one or more
/ directories.
/ Only file and directory paths matching the rules are returned. By default,
/ ignore files like `.gitignore` are respected. The precise matching rules
/ and precedence is explained in the documentation for `WalkBuilder`.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Creates a new recursive directory iterator for the file path given.

attributes.value: / Creates a new recursive directory iterator for the file path given.
/ Note that this uses default settings, which include respecting
/ `.gitignore` files. To configure the iterator, use `WalkBuilder`
/ instead.

defs.name: Continue
defs.docs: Continue walking as normal.

attributes.value: / Continue walking as normal.

defs.name: Skip
defs.docs:
If the directory entry given is a directory, don't descend into it.
 In all other cases, this has no effect.

attributes.value: / If the directory entry given is a directory, don't descend into it.
/ In all other cases, this has no effect.

defs.name: Quit
defs.docs: Quit the entire iterator as soon as possible.

attributes.value: / Quit the entire iterator as soon as possible.
/ Note that this is an inherently asynchronous action. It is possible
/ for more entries to be yielded even after instructing the iterator
/ to quit.

defs.name: WalkState
defs.docs:
WalkState is used in the parallel recursive directory iterator to indicate
 whether walking should continue as normal, skip descending into a
 particular directory or quit the walk entirely.

attributes.value: / WalkState is used in the parallel recursive directory iterator to indicate
/ whether walking should continue as normal, skip descending into a
/ particular directory or quit the walk entirely.

defs.name: ParallelVisitorBuilder
defs.docs:
A builder for constructing a visitor when using
 [`WalkParallel::visit`](struct.WalkParallel.html#method.visit). The builder
 will be called for each thread started by `WalkParallel`. The visitor
 returned from each builder is then called for every directory entry.

attributes.value: / A builder for constructing a visitor when using
/ [`WalkParallel::visit`](struct.WalkParallel.html#method.visit). The builder
/ will be called for each thread started by `WalkParallel`. The visitor
/ returned from each builder is then called for every directory entry.

defs.name: build
defs.docs: Create per-thread `ParallelVisitor`s for `WalkParallel`.

attributes.value: / Create per-thread `ParallelVisitor`s for `WalkParallel`.

defs.name: ParallelVisitor
defs.docs: Receives files and directories for the current thread.

attributes.value: / Receives files and directories for the current thread.
/ Setup for the traversal can be implemented as part of
/ [`ParallelVisitorBuilder::build`](trait.ParallelVisitorBuilder.html#tymethod.build).
/ Teardown when traversal finishes can be implemented by implementing the
/ `Drop` trait on your traversal type.

defs.name: visit
defs.value: pub fn visit(&mut Self, Result<DirEntry, Error>) -> WalkState
defs.docs:
Receives files and directories for the current thread. This is called
 once for every directory entry visited by traversal.

attributes.value: / Receives files and directories for the current thread. This is called
/ once for every directory entry visited by traversal.

defs.name: WalkParallel
defs.docs:
WalkParallel is a parallel recursive directory iterator over files paths
 in one or more directories.

attributes.value: / WalkParallel is a parallel recursive directory iterator over files paths
/ in one or more directories.
/ Only file and directory paths matching the rules are returned. By default,
/ ignore files like `.gitignore` are respected. The precise matching rules
/ and precedence is explained in the documentation for `WalkBuilder`.
/ Unlike `Walk`, this uses multiple threads for traversing a directory.

defs.name: run
defs.value: pub fn run<'s, F>(Self, F) where F: FnMut() -> FnVisitor
defs.docs:
Execute the parallel recursive directory iterator. `mkf` is called
 for each thread used for iteration. The function produced by `mkf`
 is then in turn called for each visited file path.

attributes.value: / Execute the parallel recursive directory iterator. `mkf` is called
/ for each thread used for iteration. The function produced by `mkf`
/ is then in turn called for each visited file path.

defs.name: visit
defs.docs:
Execute the parallel recursive directory iterator using a custom
 visitor.

attributes.value: / Execute the parallel recursive directory iterator using a custom
/ visitor.
/ The builder given is used to construct a visitor for every thread
/ used by this traversal. The visitor returned from each builder is then
/ called for every directory entry seen by that thread.
/ Typically, creating a custom visitor is useful if you need to perform
/ some kind of cleanup once traversal is finished. This can be achieved
/ by implementing `Drop` for your builder (or for your visitor, if you
/ want to execute cleanup for every thread that is launched).
/ For example, each visitor might build up a data structure of results
/ corresponding to the directory entries seen for each thread. Since each
/ visitor runs on only one thread, this build-up can be done without
/ synchronization. Then, once traversal is complete, all of the results
/ can be merged together into a single data structure.

defs.name: Partial
defs.docs:
A collection of "soft" errors. These occur when adding an ignore
 file partially succeeded.

attributes.value: / A collection of "soft" errors. These occur when adding an ignore
/ file partially succeeded.

defs.name: WithLineNumber
defs.docs: An error associated with a specific line number.

attributes.value: / An error associated with a specific line number.

defs.name: WithPath
defs.docs: An error associated with a particular file path.

attributes.value: / An error associated with a particular file path.

defs.name: WithDepth
defs.docs:
An error associated with a particular directory depth when recursively
 walking a directory.

attributes.value: / An error associated with a particular directory depth when recursively
/ walking a directory.

defs.name: Loop
defs.docs:
An error that occurs when a file loop is detected when traversing
 symbolic links.

attributes.value: / An error that occurs when a file loop is detected when traversing
/ symbolic links.

defs.name: Io
defs.docs: An error that occurs when doing I/O, such as reading an ignore file.

attributes.value: / An error that occurs when doing I/O, such as reading an ignore file.

defs.name: Glob
defs.docs: An error that occurs when trying to parse a glob.

attributes.value: / An error that occurs when trying to parse a glob.

defs.name: UnrecognizedFileType
defs.docs: A type selection for a file type that is not defined.

attributes.value: / A type selection for a file type that is not defined.

defs.name: InvalidDefinition
defs.docs: A user specified file type definition could not be parsed.

attributes.value: / A user specified file type definition could not be parsed.

defs.name: Error
defs.docs: Represents an error that can occur when parsing a gitignore file.

attributes.value: / Represents an error that can occur when parsing a gitignore file.

defs.name: is_partial
defs.docs: Returns true if this is a partial error.

attributes.value: / Returns true if this is a partial error.
/ A partial error occurs when only some operations failed while others
/ may have succeeded. For example, an ignore file may contain an invalid
/ glob among otherwise valid globs.

defs.name: is_io
defs.docs: Returns true if this error is exclusively an I/O error.

attributes.value: / Returns true if this error is exclusively an I/O error.

defs.name: io_error
defs.docs: Inspect the original [`io::Error`] if there is one.

attributes.value: / Inspect the original [`io::Error`] if there is one.
/ [`None`] is returned if the [`Error`] doesn't correspond to an
/ [`io::Error`]. This might happen, for example, when the error was
/ produced because a cycle was found in the directory tree while
/ following symbolic links.
/ This method returns a borrowed value that is bound to the lifetime of the [`Error`]. To
/ obtain an owned value, the [`into_io_error`] can be used instead.
/ > This is the original [`io::Error`] and is _not_ the same as
/ > [`impl From<Error> for std::io::Error`][impl] which contains additional context about the
/ error.
/ [`None`]: https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/option/enum.Option.html#variant.None
/ [`io::Error`]: https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/io/struct.Error.html
/ [`From`]: https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/convert/trait.From.html
/ [`Error`]: struct.Error.html
/ [`into_io_error`]: struct.Error.html#method.into_io_error
/ [impl]: struct.Error.html#impl-From%3CError%3E

defs.name: into_io_error
defs.docs:
Similar to [`io_error`] except consumes self to convert to the original
 [`io::Error`] if one exists.

attributes.value: / Similar to [`io_error`] except consumes self to convert to the original
/ [`io::Error`] if one exists.
/ [`io_error`]: struct.Error.html#method.io_error
/ [`io::Error`]: https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/io/struct.Error.html

defs.name: depth
defs.docs:
Returns a depth associated with recursively walking a directory (if
 this error was generated from a recursive directory iterator).

attributes.value: / Returns a depth associated with recursively walking a directory (if
/ this error was generated from a recursive directory iterator).

defs.name: None
defs.docs: The path didn't match any glob.

attributes.value: / The path didn't match any glob.

defs.name: Ignore
defs.docs:
The highest precedent glob matched indicates the path should be
 ignored.

attributes.value: / The highest precedent glob matched indicates the path should be
/ ignored.

defs.name: Whitelist
defs.docs:
The highest precedent glob matched indicates the path should be
 whitelisted.

attributes.value: / The highest precedent glob matched indicates the path should be
/ whitelisted.

defs.name: Match
defs.docs: The result of a glob match.

attributes.value: / The result of a glob match.
/ The type parameter `T` typically refers to a type that provides more
/ information about a particular match. For example, it might identify
/ the specific gitignore file and the specific glob pattern that caused
/ the match.

defs.name: is_none
defs.docs: Returns true if the match result didn't match any globs.

attributes.value: / Returns true if the match result didn't match any globs.

defs.name: is_ignore
defs.docs: Returns true if the match result implies the path should be ignored.

attributes.value: / Returns true if the match result implies the path should be ignored.

defs.name: is_whitelist
defs.docs:
Returns true if the match result implies the path should be
 whitelisted.

attributes.value: / Returns true if the match result implies the path should be
/ whitelisted.

defs.name: invert
defs.docs:
Inverts the match so that `Ignore` becomes `Whitelist` and
 `Whitelist` becomes `Ignore`. A non-match remains the same.

attributes.value: / Inverts the match so that `Ignore` becomes `Whitelist` and
/ `Whitelist` becomes `Ignore`. A non-match remains the same.

defs.name: inner
defs.docs: Return the value inside this match if it exists.

attributes.value: / Return the value inside this match if it exists.

defs.name: map
defs.value: pub fn map<U, F: FnOnce(T) -> U>(Self, F) -> Match<U>
defs.docs: Apply the given function to the value inside this match.

attributes.value: / Apply the given function to the value inside this match.
/ If the match has no value, then return the match unchanged.

defs.name: or
defs.docs: Return the match if it is not none. Otherwise, return other.

attributes.value: / Return the match if it is not none. Otherwise, return other.
